subtitle: Place your advance order now on Amazon for the very first volume of the New Thinking
Allowed Dialogue Series, Is There Life After Death?
Publication date is June 1st.
Thinking Allowed. Conversations on the leading
edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist
Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome. I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we'll be exploring reincarnation as it's
experienced in tribal societies. With me is
anthropologist Dr. James Matlock, who is the
co-author with Erlander Haraldson of a recently
published book titled, I Saw a Light and Came
Here, Children's Experiences of Reincarnation.
Dr. Matlock has published dozens of academic papers
and book chapters on the subject of reincarnation
and related fields. He is the developer of an
academic course called Signs of Reincarnation,
which to my knowledge is the only such academic
course anywhere focusing exclusively on the experimental and field studies evidence for
reincarnation. In addition, he is a regular contributor to the online PSI Encyclopedia
sponsored by the Society for Psychical Research in England. Welcome, Jim.
Thank you.
You pretty much have spent your professional
career in anthropology looking at reincarnation
and its many different manifestations both in
scientific research and in tribal societies
throughout the whole world.
Yes, I have. I came to anthropology from parapsychology. I already had developed my
interest in reincarnation in working with
Stevenson's cases and had come to be acquainted
with the phenomenology of those cases, including
the things we've talked about in earlier
conversations, the memories of children, as well
as the behavioral patterns and the birthmarks.
I might mention for our viewers, this is our
ninth interview now, so for people who really
want to dig into the literature, check our listings for the previous eight.
Well, anyway, so when I came to anthropology
then, I chose that as my professional field.
I was interested, first of all, in whether reincarnation beliefs appeared elsewhere in
the world. And as I began to look into that, I
discovered not only were there beliefs everywhere
in tribal societies throughout the world, but
when ethnographers and anthropologists had
reported them, they had reported in association
with the beliefs the same sorts of signs that
were studied by Stevenson and his colleagues in conjunction with cases.
In other words, these tribal societies intuitively used an empirical approach in
developing their reincarnation beliefs. Yes, and it's not only the reincarnation
beliefs, but survival beliefs in general are
empirically based in observations and experiences.
Edward Tyler, Sir Edward Tyler, who wrote a
book called Animism. Back in the 19th century,
as I recall. That's right, it was first published
in 1871, it's gone through several editions.
Yeah. It was first published in 1871, and he reviewed, at that time there was not any
real anthropology, no professional anthropology,
but he reviewed reports from tribal societies,
from indigenous societies throughout the world,
from colonial administrators, missionaries,
travelers, many of whom had described under
the heading of religious beliefs or simply of
cultural traits, the belief in reincarnation
and associated with that these signs, and more
generally, you know, survival, you know, beliefs.
And Tyler pointed out that these are often
associated with what we now call apparitions,
near-death experiences, out-of-body experiences,
that could be dreams in which human figures appeared, and so forth.
In other words, the modern notion that these
tribal societies were very primitive and they
had superstitious animistic beliefs completely
ungrounded from reality is not what Tyler found.
Well, no, and it's not what he was talking about
when he he labeled these animism, animistic
beliefs. What he had in mind was the spirit
beliefs grounded in experience as a conclusion
from experience. And he did the same thing with
reincarnation. He found an empirical basis for
that too, in the same sorts of signs which we
study today, the birthmarks, the announcing dreams,
the children's claims to remember having lived
before. You know, and so it was quite interesting
to see that not only were these beliefs grounded
in these observations and experiences, they were
empirically based, but that these are the very
same signs that we study today in parapsychology
as evidence of survival. Well, most people, I
imagine many of our viewers are going to assume
that reincarnation is a concept that comes to
us from Hindu culture, and we don't find it
elsewhere. That's simply not true. It's simply not
true, no. There's an axiom of anthropology that
the more widespread a trait is, the older
it's likely to be. And in my research, I found
reincarnation beliefs and cases on every
continent except Antarctica, understandably.
There's no population there.
To have experienced these things, so we can understand why. But everywhere else,
and not just on the continents, in most areas of
the continents too, including Europe. If you go
back, you find reincarnation beliefs and cases
reported among the Scandinavian peoples, among
the Gauls, the Celts. Well, I don't have a number,
but I would imagine if you were to try to count
all of the different indigenous peoples, maybe
according to their language, or some way to
demarcate one from another. I know that even gets
tricky. We're probably talking over a thousand.
Oh, easily. Yeah, many thousands.
Many thousands.
Yeah, I would say. Because there's just so many of these different tribal societies,
each with its own language, each with its own
culture. And even in the same area, you may find
a lot of different languages or dialects spoken and different cultural practices.
And probably within the anthropological community, these have all been enumerated.
You know, all is maybe a strong word, but certainly many of them have been studied.
I know every now and then they seem to discover a new…
I know. But I'm not even sure that every single group that's known has been studied
in anthropology. But certainly a good number of them have been.
A good number of them have been. Let's assume over a thousand in any case.
Yes, yes. And the cross-cultural studies, which
have worked with these, have found reincarnation
beliefs in anywhere from about 37% to upwards
of 50% of the societies in a given sample.
So to a third, to maybe a bit over a half.
Right. Of the indigenous societies. You know,
this is based on the samples, the study samples.
But I think it's fair to generalize from them
and say that maybe roughly half of indigenous
societies have been reported to have reincarnation
beliefs, often with accompanying signs.
And I think we can safely assume that these
beliefs are probably quite old, prehistorical
in these societies. And that these various
cultures, let's say the Aborigines of Australia
and the North American Indians of the Northwest
or Alaska have had very little contact, if any
contact. For a very long time, yes. I mean, we
know that, you know, the human species originated
in Africa but would have dispersed out of Africa
quite a long time ago. You know, so that's right.
Australian Aborigines would have had very little
contact with the West Africans for a very long
time, West Africa being another area in which we find these beliefs quite commonly.
So it's probably fair to assume that these
beliefs originated independently and based on,
as you have pointed out, the tendency of these
indigenous people to observe the various empirical
phenomenon that we are also observing, that point towards reincarnation belief.
Right. Well, I would say, you know, it's hard
to know what to infer from this data in terms of
the origin of the beliefs. But definitely we can
say that even if an original human population
had reincarnation beliefs, then that's entirely possible. But that it's the signs,
these different signs that we've been talking
about, the behaviors and the physical signs and
Yes, which we have elaborated on in great detail in previous interviews.
Right, right. That those would have supported
the belief and could easily have given rise
to different beliefs. And as we learn more about the history of human population,
it becomes more and more complex even in Africa.
So there may very well not have been an original
society from which we're all developed, but it could be much more complex.
Now, let me make sure I catch that. It sounds
like what you just said is the further away you go
from human origins in Africa, the more complex the beliefs become.
No, well, what I'm saying is in terms of human
origins and the development of the human species,
the more we get into the fossil record and
so forth, the more we realize this is really
a very complex picture. And it's far too simplistic to say there was some sort of
aboriginal human population from which all of the humans emerged. It's more likely to,
it's much more complex than that, much more
branching than that, which implies, I believe,
that the signs that seem to have given rise to
reincarnation belief and definitely support them
these days may have been part of not only of the
human heritage but of the pre-human heritage.
Mm-hmm. I mean hominids.
Yes. I mean, you know, they may have experienced
birthmarks and behavioral patterns and,
you know, who knows? I mean, even memories. So we have no idea how far back
reincarnation goes. And in fact, if reincarnation
is a fact, we would expect it to have shown up,
you know, before humans arrived. I mean, there's
no reason why it would suddenly appear when humans
appeared. Well, part of your study looks at
the various cultural patterns of the different
indigenous tribes. There's wide variation amongst them.
There really is, yes.
And the way in which their reincarnation beliefs interact with some of their,
for example, kinship patterns.
And other social practices, too, is really very interesting.
There are just a variety of social practices
in animistic societies and tribal societies
that are related to reincarnation beliefs,
as if the practices arose as a way of taking
advantage of the beliefs, you know, in other words,
which for them weren't beliefs, after all. They
were scientific observations.
From their point of view, it was based on
observable, what we would call empirical reality.
Empirical reality.
Through the normal senses.
Right. And so, you know, I don't think it's wrong to characterize that as a scientific
observation. And so, for them, reincarnation was an accepted part of life.
And in developing these practices, I'm suggesting,
they were trying to take advantage of the fact
that we return, you know, after we die.
For example?
Well, an example of an advantage would be one
of the things we see in many of these societies
is practices that seem to be designed to identify
the person through the name, by giving them the
same name, and then through the name, allow them
to inherit property and both tangible property.
The practice of naming a child after a deceased ancestor.
Right. Based on signs.
Then is tied to the inheritance of material and immaterial property, like status.
Yeah. Yeah, because a lot of people joke today,
I hope I can be reborn and then I can inherit
my wealth. If I put $100 in the bank now and
I'm reborn in 100 years, imagine what that
will be with compound interest.
Yes, yeah. Absolutely.
So, but this is, I mean, it's a fantasy for modern people to think that way, but in
indigenous cultures, there may have been more gratuit.
I believe so, yes. You know, I believe so.
And there are other practices too, which seem
to be designed to take advantage of reincarnation.
For instance, in many societies, you find
children, particularly children, but sometimes
adults too, buried in the home, in the floor of
the home, or by paths to facilitate the return
to the same parents or in the community.
Yeah. Well, it is my understanding that a lot of the modern western distaste that we
have for corpses and for the dead is not shared by tribal societies.
Not always. Sometimes it is. Sometimes you get the, you know, a great fear of the dead
because, you know, there is the idea in some
societies that apparitions may be hanging
around, ghosts may be hanging around the dead,
and if you go near them, the ghosts won't
company and so they may cause you to die too.
But if you bury your relative under your
kitchen floor, you probably don't feel that way.
You probably don't feel that way, that's right. Where you do find beliefs like that,
there may be a good reason for it. You know, it may
be that somebody died from a contagious disease,
you know, and if you don't know that it was a contagious disease, you can still observe
if somebody goes near that body, they might catch the same disease and pass on too.
And therefore, one can see how, again, you come back to empirical observations
leading to beliefs and to practices.
So the fundamental lesson in all of this seems
to me to be that because people come from a
primitive society does not mean that they
as individuals are less intelligent and less
capable than city dwellers.
Absolutely not. Or that their cultures are
less sophisticated. They're just sophisticated
in a different way. Another way that reincarnation
shows up is, as you suggested, in the kinship
patterns. There are societies that, unlike
our society, reckon kinship either through the
father or the mother alone. We do it bilaterally.
We don't, you know, make a strong distinction
there. But there are societies who recognize only
the father or only the mother is transmitting
kinship in the society. And interestingly enough,
in those societies, we see the reincarnation
patterns that is not only the beliefs now, but
when we look at the cases and what we call solved
cases, ones in which the previous person spoken about has been identified.
And here we're again talking about typically
spontaneous memories reported by children.
That's correct, yes. So when we look at cases
in which there is an identified previous person
associated with in agreement with the
children's memories, behaviors, and so forth,
in tribal cultures that have these unilinear
concepts of kinship, the cases fall in the
appropriate line. For instance, the Tlingit Indians
of Alaska are matrilineal, and the cases there
fall predominantly on the mother's side. Not exclusively. Not exclusively. There are
exceptions. Now the belief is, the ideal is, that
they do. And it can create problems sometimes
when science suggests something else. So that suggests that the cultural belief
is impacting the actual operation of reincarnation. It does, doesn't it? I mean,
the converse example would be the Igbo of
Nigeria, who are patrilineal. And there we find
the cases on the father's side. So the fact that
the spirit after death seemingly can discriminate
and decide that it's going to go in the appropriate,
we're going to connect to the appropriate
relative on the mother's side versus the father's
side, does suggest that there is some control.
Well, in either case, the notion is that the
reincarnation takes place within the family.
Yes. Or within the family line, at least. The
extended family. Yeah, within the extended family,
at least within. It becomes a little bit too
technical to describe how they reckon kinship.
You know, so sometimes what they reckon as a
maternal relative may not be exactly what we
mean by in the family. I see. So that's why I'm
hedging a little bit there. In the family line,
in the maternal line versus the paternal line.
Okay, well that's important. But of course,
the other alternative explanation would be that if
a case is discordant with cultural expectations,
the people are less likely to make it known
so that researchers wouldn't be aware of it.
Well, that's true. That's true. But we do have cases
in most of these societies that are discordant.
And we can then look at and see how they're
handled. And they're sometimes recognized and
sometimes not, depending on the culture. But they
can't be socially recognized in the same way.
If you're not born to the appropriate relative
to receive your name, you can't receive it
back again. And if you don't receive your name
back again, then you're not eligible to inherit
your property. So there is this incentive then
to follow the cultural norms. Well, it does sound
like, as has been my understanding, that tribal
societies do tend to be more rigid about these
things. In their ideology, yes. I mean, if you're
living in a tribal culture, it's very different
from living in a cosmopolitan culture. Yes. I mean, you're talking about a much smaller
community. And shared beliefs. Right. But there
are different social organizations that I want
to give the impression that all of them are
either matrilineal or patrilineal. There are some
bilateral ones, too. Yes. And with the bilateral
ones, we do not see a tendency for the cases to
cluster on either the mother's or father's side.
They again follow the social organization in being
bilateral. Well, all of this would be consistent
with your view, I gather, that the deceased
person has some control psychologically within their consciousness as to the
how and when and where they might reincarnate.
Yes, absolutely. And then I might mention that
in tribal cultures is something else that we don't
find when we get outside of the tribal realm when
we move into state-level societies in Asia and
the West. And that is the idea that you can plan
before death where you're going to be reborn.
Now, you know, in Tibet, you know, you do have
advanced lamas and so forth saying that they're
going to be reborn in a specific place or, you
know, in a general place, in a general area, but
they never tell you specifically where they're
going to be reborn. Whereas in the tribal cultures,
that's more common. They often do, yes. They will
say, they'll pick out their future family, their
future mother, and explain why they want to go
there. They'll sometimes say, you can, you'll
be able to identify me by this or that mark,
and it shows up. And then also the announcing
dreams. And announcing dreams are very important.
Tribal cultures. I'm guessing that tribal cultures
tend to pay more attention to dreams in general
than cosmopolitan cultures. I suspect so. And
anthropologists who have worked with dreams
have pointed out that the dreams in these societies often appear to be more realistic
than the dreams we experience here for some
reason. And they also more often seem to include
the images of spirits, including in these
announcing dreams, which are dreams that are
had by a pregnant woman or a woman shortly to
become pregnant, or sometimes her husband or
another relative, in which the spirit of a deceased person appears and
represents that they intend to be reborn in that family. And I gather in some of these
tribal societies you have shamans who are specialists in helping to determine the
identification of a newly born person, who it is
exactly that they might be the incarnation of.
Yes, you do. And this can be of assistance when
there are not sufficient signs to indicate who
a newborn was. You go to the shaman or the priest
or the oracle, and they make the identification.
And Tony Mills has a case in which there was a
child born without announcing dreams, without
birthmarks. They took the child to the shaman, and
the shaman made the identification that they was
a relative to the dreamer. Then as the child grew up,
he was taken back to the location where the previous person had died accidentally.
He recognized the place. Memories then began
to flow, and he talked more about his memories.
Visiting that location served as a trigger.
It served as a trigger. But what was interesting
is that this was the same person that the shaman
had identified him as having been. So, well,
maybe the grandparents who took him back there,
they would have known this story. They would have known about the identification.
So you can say, well, maybe a skeptic might say,
you know, the grandparents helped shape this.
Maybe he was told by his parents or grandparents
as who he was. But nevertheless, it is interesting
that some years after the shaman made the
identification, the child does develop these
memories. Well, you know, there's a funny paradox
in this because as I talk to reincarnation
researchers, I get the feeling that on the one
hand, they have a pretty low opinion in general
of information that comes from so-called psychics or mediums. But when it comes to
indigenous cultures and to the shamanistic
practitioners within an indigenous community,
the researchers seem to have a higher regard for the work that they do.
Yes, I think so. I think that's fair to say. And this is consistent with
the empirical basis of their beliefs. You know,
they've observed also that there is such a thing
as telepathy and clairvoyance and that there
can be people, specialists, very often shamans,
who are specialized in these practices and in mediumistic practices and so forth,
in contacting the spirit world and bringing back information from the spirit world.
Do you think there's a bias against the contemporary practitioners?
In what way? That they're held in lower esteem than
indigenous shamans? You mean in western society? Yes, yeah.
Yeah, I think so. I mean, you know, you would have subpopulations, subgroups
that have these beliefs, but the dominant culture
that we live in does not respect them, no.
I see. So I'm just wondering if this is true with regard to
tribal beliefs in general, that
anthropologists just favor tribal cultures over
their western cultures from which most of them originated.
Right. Well, anthropologists who are drawn to these tribal cultures generally become
more interested in these things. That is, you know,
Sai experiences and signs of reincarnation and signs of survival simply because they
hear about them all the time and they want
to understand the beliefs of the people that
they're working with. I have another hypothesis
and I don't want to get too far off track with
this, but it just occurred to me that if I'm an
anthropologist and I become friendly with the
local neighborhood palm reader, for example, and I
announce to my colleagues that I've been studying
palm readers and I find them to be accurate, I'm
going to be laughed at. They're going to make
fun of me and my career and my livelihood will be
threatened. But if I go to Borneo and I spend time
with the Dayak natives in Borneo and I become
friendly with a local shaman and I write an
academic paper about how this shaman has certain
gifts that are recognized and acknowledged and
seem important within his culture, I'm safe.
People aren't going to laugh at me. Right,
but many anthropologists can't, they bring their
skepticism with them and even though they're
describing these things, they still maintain
a distance from them and so they don't come to
accept them, to believe in them. Well, originally,
the standard view in anthropology was that
shamans were schizophrenic. Right. It took a while
for the discipline to disabuse itself of that
notion and get beyond that. That was out there
for a while. So there are many, what can you say,
the field of anthropology has evolved quite a
bit since those days. It has. One thing I want
to mention, coming back to social practices and so forth, an interesting facet to that,
that Antonia Mills has brought out in an edited
book that she did called Emery Indian Rebirth.
She has a paper there about the Gitsken practice
of wearing earrings, high status individuals
wear earrings and she describes a series of cases
of young children born with earring birthmarks,
which I find interesting. There are other earring
birthmarks turn up in other parts of the world,
too. Ian Stevenson has quite a few in his reincarnation in biology. But in
indigenous societies, these earring birthmarks
help not only to identify the child specifically
as a high status individual reborn. Very interesting. Now in one of our earlier
interviews, we talked about the practice of,
I think we called it experimental birthmarks,
where a body is marked in order to see whether a
young child, a baby will be born with those same
markings as a way to identify the new incarnation.
Is that a practice that is common amongst
indigenous tribes? No, I wouldn't say so. It's
very widespread in Asia. You find it all the way
across Asia. But it's mostly reported not in
the indigenous tribes, but in the more developed
societies, which suggests that it's a practice
that has some time depth, but was not a part of
the original indigenous tribal societies. It
seems to have evolved later and yet spread
quite far. I mean, we find it all the way from
Burma, Thailand, through China, across to Japan,
even. I see. Well, with regard to tribal cultures, is there anything more we should
add before we conclude this program? Off the top of my head, I
can't think of anything. Okay, no, I think we've
done a good job of covering it once again. I think
we have, yes. Dr. James Matlock, thank you so much.
And thank you. And thank you for being with us as
well.
